title: 107_s1263
content: The "Voluntary Medicare Prescription Drug Plan Act of 2001" establishes Medicare payment for outpatient prescription drugs under Part D, which includes options like the Medicare Prescription Drug Plan and Rx Option. It also allows partnerships with private entities to offer the Rx Option. Additionally, there are conforming changes to Medigap. The Medicare Prescription Drug Plan Act of 2001 introduces Part D for outpatient prescription drug coverage. Eligible individuals can enroll in the Rx Option to receive coverage and pay a combined deductible. The Medicare Prescription Drug Plan Act of 2001 introduces Part D for outpatient prescription drug coverage. Eligible individuals can enroll in the Rx Option, with a 2-year obligation and a free look period. The Rx Option allows individuals to disenroll within the first full month after enrollment. Enrollees can only have a Medicare supplemental policy alongside the Rx Option. Starting in 2002, the Secretary provides outpatient prescription drug benefits through private entities, covering 50% of the cost after meeting the deductible. The cost-of-living adjustment for prescription drug expenses is calculated based on the Consumer Price Index. The cost-of-living adjustment for prescription drug expenses is calculated based on the Consumer Price Index, with any increase rounded to the nearest dollar. The combined deductible is calculated based on the Consumer Price Index. Beginning in 2002, beneficiaries electing the Rx Option will have a combined deductible of $675, which replaces deductibles under other sections. This amount will be adjusted annually based on the Consumer Price Index. The combined deductible for beneficiaries electing the Rx Option starting in 2002 is $675, adjusted annually based on the Consumer Price Index. The deductible applies to each expense incurred on a calendar year basis for covered items or services, with any increase rounded to the nearest dollar. Partnerships with private entities to offer the Rx option. The Secretary will contract with private entities, including insurers, pharmaceutical benefit managers, chain pharmacies, and independent pharmacies, to provide outpatient prescription drug benefits under the Rx Option on a local, regional, or national basis. Drug benefits will only be offered through private entities under this section. The Secretary must contract with any qualified private entity to provide outpatient prescription drug benefits under the Rx Option, as long as the entity meets all requirements set by the Secretary. SEC. 3. CONFORMING CHANGES TO MEDIGAP. Section 1882 of the Social Security Act is amended to include special rules for Medicare Prescription Drug Plan Enrollees, requiring revisions to benefit packages to include specific rules for individuals enrolled in the Rx Option under section 1860B. Each benefit package requires the beneficiary to pay annual out-of-pocket expenses equal to the combined deductible before receiving any benefits. Policies classified as 'H', 'I', and 'J' cannot duplicate coverage for outpatient prescription drugs provided under the Rx Option. Adjusted premiums may apply in certain cases. Adjusted premiums may be applied for individuals enrolled in the Rx Option to reflect special rules. Revisions to benefit packages do not affect the renewal or continuity of coverage under existing Medicare supplemental policies.
